relations.sentence: (Bloomberg) -- Investors are bracing for more debt defaults among China's cash-squeezed real estate developers as funding costs surge and refinancing pressure intensifies.
Junk-rated China Evergrande Group, the nation's second largest builder by sales, sold $1.8 billion three-tranche notes last week.

"Evergrande is the latest lower-rated issuer to re-price offshore bond markets wider, as the onshore private sector credit crunch continues to bite," said Owen Gallimore, head of credit strategy from Australia & New Zealand Banking Group.

Borrowing costs in dollars for China's high-yield issuers, most of whom are property developers, almost doubled this year to 11.2 percent, the highest in about four years, ICE BofAML indexes show.

China's property developers have been caught in the storm of a funding crunch facing the nation's private sector due to a two-year long clampdown on shadow financing.
Although authorities have rolled out measures to ease funding for non-state firms, the existing property control policies won't loosen, the official Xinhua New Agency said in a commentary last week.
